Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

   Cedric, I guess those all rithorical questions. Aren't they?

>>>>  Justification? This is just how JUnit resolve test cases.
>>>I mean:  how come the test fails if you fail to call the super
>>>constructor
>>>with a string?
>>>
>>>It's so counterintuitive that it tripped even Elliotte...  (and myself
>>>many times).
>>>
>>  Was it you who said that he always using assertNull(value) without a
>>description?
> 
> Not sure what this has to do with my question.

   Test would of failed with a error "Invalid test name null" or 
something like that.
   That imho would be better then throwing exception manually like 
Eliott suggested.

> Which was:  depending on whether you create your tests yourself or you let
> JUnit create them, you need to call super(String) or super().
> Why?

   As I said, it is related to test discovery. There has to be two 
cobstructors where first one is used in autodiscovery. It is basically 
to allow to not declare explicit constructors in TestCase subclasses. 
  I guess they should of thrown a runtime exception from the default 
conctructor because it not suppose to be called. The actual 
constructor used to create a test case is the one with test name argument.

> And a side question:  if you use the parameterized test pattern, it's okay
> to do your initialization in the constructor, whereas setUp() is usually the
> recommended place in the other cases.

   If you ask me, I always keep test creation and test setup separate. 
First one just saving all params to the fields. The deal with this all 
about class loading and initialization of the test suites. Do I need 
to explain all the mechanics? :-)

   regards,
   Eugene
